identificationModule.briefTitle: Screening, Early Referral and Lifestyle Tailored E_prescription for Cardiovascular Prevention
identificationModule.officialTitle: Screening, Early Referral and Lifestyle Tailored E_prescription for Cardiovascular Prevention in PakisTan(SELECT) - A Pilot Feasibility Study Using mHealth

responsibleParty.investigatorTitle: Professor of Neurology, Department of Medicine

descriptionModule.briefSummary: We will evaluate an e_Prescription intervention can be integrated into an electronic screening program, which together exploit: (i) reach - the adult population has 100% mobile phone ownership and 92% internet national coverage; and (ii) behavioral change - the intervention can teach verbally and visually, thus bypassing literacy challenges, to allow simple, low-cost, repetition messaging for habit reinforcement. Uptake of the program through the various stages will be evaluated in \~2000 adults of a large representative suburban district of Karachi: As well as before-and-after physiological measures, including blood pressure (BP) and blood glucose, a random sample of 30-40 participants will be invited for interview to assess success and failure of the program. This is a pragmatic feasibility intervention implementation study.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
The goal of this pilot study is to demonstrate feasibility of a scalable , population-wide, approach to early detection and management of people at high-risk of CVD using electronic screening, referral, treatment and lifestyle modification based on health theory and considerable background research for local applicability.

It is a mixed method, feasibility study based in Malir District of Karachi, the largest city in Pakistan, to demonstrate uptake, participation and response of our mHealth intervention.

interventions.name: SELECT mHealth Program
interventions.description: Individuals will be screened via the telephone, using a mobile-based algorithm that prompts questions about hypertension, risk of Diabetes Mellitus, use of smokeless tobacco and smoking, level of physical activity, and main nutritional choices. These questions are based on tools that have been validated in studies undertaken in this population and will be directly administered by trained research staff of Aga Khan University. Screening will prompt triage into three categories: "high" - referred to the conveniently located integrated medical center for a medical teleconsultation and fasting glucose test; "medium" - receive fasting glucose test and BP measurement; and "low" risk. All subjects in each category will be enrolled in an e_Prescription intervention for lifestyle change tailored to their individual risk profile.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Health Service Delivery of Intervention Outreach via Short Text Messages
primaryOutcomes.description:
The success rate in delivery of SMS intervention to target community

1. Number of SMS sent successfully to target Population

primaryOutcomes.measure: Health Service Delivery of Intervention Outreach via Interactive Voice Recording
primaryOutcomes.description: Number of IVR ( Interactive Voice Recording ) sent to target Population

primaryOutcomes.measure: Health Service Measures of Intervention Uptake
primaryOutcomes.description: Proportion of referred participants enrolled in e_Prescription education program

primaryOutcomes.measure: Community Participation and Uptake of Intervention
primaryOutcomes.description: Number of participants responded to the IVR and SMS call

primaryOutcomes.measure: Early Impact Measure of Intervention for Prompt Referral
primaryOutcomes.description: Proportion of referred participants from screened participants referred

primaryOutcomes.measure: Early Impact Measure of Intervention for Detection
primaryOutcomes.description:
Proportion of participants in each of risk strata (low, medium and high risk) as defined by

the presence of stroke and/or MI ( High ), DM and / or HTN ( Medium), or poor lifestyle choices ( Low Risk) by the SELECT algorithm

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Physiological Characteristics of Intervention Participants - Blood Pressure
secondaryOutcomes.description: Mean difference in systolic and diastolic Blood Pressure before and after intervention in mm Hg.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Physiological Characteristics of Intervention Participants - Weight
secondaryOutcomes.description: Mean difference in weight before and after intervention in kg

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Physiologic Characteristics of Intervention Participants- Height
secondaryOutcomes.description: Height in metres to determine Body Mass Index ( BMI )

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Physiological Characteristics of Intervention Participants - BMI
secondaryOutcomes.description: Mean difference in BMI before and after intervention in kg/m2

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Physiological Characteristics of Intervention Participants - Physical Activity
secondaryOutcomes.description: Increase in number of hours in physical activity from baseline (self-reported) measured by the IPAQ Short scale self reported version ( International Physical Activity Questionnaire) which will report low medium and high levels of physical activity based on 600 MET minutes /week ( Moderate),1500- 3000 MET minutes /week ( High), and low as any value less than the above.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* All adult (\>18 years) residents of Malir district
* Own a mobile phone
* Provide written informed consent are eligible to participate

Exclusion Criteria:

* Not permanent residents of Malir district.
* A person who is decision impaired due to stroke, or aphasia or dementia .
* Serious cognitive deficits that impair the visualization or understanding of SMS, IVR and e_prescription messages
eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: The pilot study will be undertaken in the Malir area (80,000 persons), one of the largest districts of Karachi (population 120 million), with urban, urban slum, and rural urban areas, and includes all ethnicities and economic strata of Pakistan. In this location, the Aga Khan University Health System, one of the major health systems of Pakistan, has integrated medical centers (IMSs) with laboratory testing, resident physicians, and ability to triage and refer people to a main tertiary hospital.
